title: Is Agatha Christie in the public domain? - Quora

response.answer_text: Generally speaking, no. In the U.K. and most of the civilized world, her works will fall into the public domain in 2046, seventy years after her death. In some countries they’ll fall into the public domain in 2026, fifty years after her death. In the United States, everything she published prior to 1925 is now in the public domain, but everything after that is still under copyright — there were no missed renewals or other screw-ups. That means just five of her sixty-six novels, and the short story collection Poirot Investigates, are in the public domain in the U.S. Nothing is, outside the U.S.

Mostly no. I humbly suggest you look right at the copyright records on the U.S. Copyright database at U.S. Copyright Office . You will find about 250 pages of copyright registrations relating to the work of Agatha Christie and derivative or related works, such as movies and sound recordings. Note that Agatha Christie is a registered “synonym” for Agatha Christie Mallowan. JA - M.S., J.D., LL.M. Intellectual Property No legal advice is intended.
